results.title: Flubber
results.creator_credit: Les Mayfield, John Hughes, Ricardo Mestres, Great Oaks and Walt Disney Pictures
results.brief_description: In this colourful remake of ‘The Absent Minded Professor’ (1961), Robin Williams plays Professor Philip Brainard, a brilliant off the wall inventor with an unfortunate short term memory. Flubber, his latest creation is a green rubber-like substance, which has the capacity to give objects flight. Potentially a gold mine for the professor and his college (which is near bankruptcy), the invention receives the unwelcome attention of Brainard’s spiteful nemesis Wilson Croft (Christopher McDonald), who has his own plans for the gravity-defying matter. The romantic subplot which involves a bizarre love triangle between Brainard, his long suffering fiance Sara (Marcia Gay Harden), and a female robot with a jealous streak called Weebo (Jodi Benson), give the film some surprisingly poignant moments, mainly due to Harden’s tender performance. Music by Danny Elfman and screenplay by John Hughes and Bill Walsh.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Les Mayfield, John Hughes, Ricardo Mestres, Great Oaks and Walt Disney Pictures

results.title: Independent company
results.creator_credit: Colin South, John Tatoulis and Media World
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Warriors”.
The story of Sparrow Force, the Australian 2/2 Independent Company, a specially trained troop of Australian soldiers sent to join Dutch forces in Timor in 1941, to defend Northern Australia against the Japanese advance. The program uses interviews with surviving Company members, as well as their Japanese opponents, mixed with re-enactments of their experiences. The interviews reveal that without the selfless assistance of the Timorese, the Australian troops would not have survived. The program also features footage shot by Academy Award winning Australian news cameraman, Damien Parer, who was killed in action in New Guinea.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Colin South, John Tatoulis and Media World

results.title: Floyd on Oz. - Volume 3.
results.creator_credit: David Pritchard, John Chase, Pam Stockley and Stockley Chase Productions
results.brief_description: Keith Floyd concludes his culinary journey around Australia with visits to the Northern Territory and Queensland. Highlights include his attempt to interest some truckies in a gourmet lunch of chicken, a meal cooked in a pit on a Queensland beach and mud crabs cooked by a rain forest river in the company of an Aboriginal dance troupe.

results.title: Fluxfilm anthology
results.brief_description: The Fluxus movement is made up of many artists blending visual arts, music and literature. The movement was founded in 1962 and has been compared to Dada and Surrealism. The artists include performance artists and video artists whose work is influenced by mystical thinking, irony and sometimes LSD. In this anthology compiled by the founder of the Fluxus movement, George Maciunas, and then later, Maeva Aubert, thirty seven pieces are gathered. Some of the videos are meant to be viewed in a loop, others use found footage and others create visual effects with a high-speed camera. The pieces range from 10 seconds to 10 minutes in length. Some of the films were screened in New York as part of the ‘happenings’ of the avant-garde. The works are often playful, undefinable reactions to everyday life. The search for meaning in life mixed with reflective, nonverbal strangeness. The artists are not necessarily known as filmmakers and include Nam June Paik, Yoko Ono, John Cale, Mike Parr, Robert Watts and Dick Higgens.

results.title: Floyd on Oz. - Volume 1.
results.creator_credit: David Pritchard, John Chase, Pam Stockley and Australia. Special Broadcasting Service
results.brief_description: In Sydney Floyd cooks a fish chowder for Sydney seafood supremo, Peter Doyle and finishes with pies and peas at the famous Harry’s Cafe de Wheels. In Tasmania Floyd creates seasonal autumn dishes. In Victoria Floyd becomes the cook for legendary horseman Jack Lovick. And in South Australia Floyd tastes some “Aussie” food: yabbies, razorfish and kangaroo-tail soup.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Pritchard, John Chase, Pam Stockley and Australia. Special Broadcasting Service

results.title: Fluteman
results.creator_credit: Peter Maxwell, Brendon Lunney and Independent Productions (AU)
results.brief_description: Minyaka is a town in need of miracles and happiness. Desperate for water and ruled by dishonest councillors they cannot even afford a swimming pool. A mysterious stranger, known only as the ‘Fluteman’ promises that he can create rain, for a cost. The councillors, (not believing his promise) agree to the sum of $5,000. The Fluteman creates rain, much the the relief of Minyaka. The councillors refuse to pay the amount promised however and Fluteman, like the Pied Piper of Hamelin, leads the children out of town in retaliation. Only a young school teacher with the assistance of her mute student can locate the children and expose the councillors to the rest of the township.

results.title: Flowers on a one way street
results.creator_credit: Robin Spry, Joseph Koenig and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Yorkville Avenue, Toronto, received newspaper prominence after it became what the papers called a “hippie haven”. This film records what happened after the young people staged demonstrations to have the street closed to traffic, and civic authorities used corresponding persuasions to keep it open as a necessary traffic artery. The main confrontation takes place at a council meeting in City Hall, to which spokesmen for the young people have come to present their case. Here the film provides opportunity to judge both their attitudes and those of the city administration. Music by The Beatles and Ravi Shankar. Photography by Douglas Kiefer and edited Christopher Cordeaux. (Awards: Chicago; New York).

results.title: Florence
results.creator_credit: Ken Wong, Mountains and Kamina Vincent
results.brief_description:
Expertly blending the visual novel and gaming genres, Florence illustrates one year in the life of a young woman in Melbourne as she falls in love, breaks her daily routine and follows her creative passion.

Developed by Australian craft games studio Mountains, Florence uses innovative gameplay mechanics to represent social interactions. The emotions of the poignant narrative are rendered through tapping and swiping minigames, making them all the more touching.
